revision.text: {{short description|Water temperature close to the ocean's surface}} {{good article}} [[File:Annual Mean Temperature Change for Land and for Ocean NASA GISTEMP 2017 October.png|320px|thumb|Annual (thin lines) and five-year lowess smooth (thick lines) for the temperature anomalies averaged over the Earth’s land area and sea surface temperature anomalies (blue line) averaged over the part of the ocean that is free of ice at all times (open ocean).]] [[File:SST 20131220 blended Global.png|thumb|This is a daily, global Sea Surface Temperature (SST) data set produced on December 20th, 2013 at 1-km resolution (also known as ultra-high resolution) by the JPL ROMS (Regional Ocean Modeling System) group.]] [[File:Weeklysst.gif|thumb|right|Weekly average '''sea surface temperature''' for the [[World Ocean]] during the first week of February 2011, during a period of [[El Niño-Southern Oscillation#Effects of ENSO's cool phase (La Niña)|La Niña]].]] [[File:ECCO2 Sea Surface Temperature and Flows.ogv|thumb|Sea surface temperature and flows.]] '''Sea surface temperature''' (SST) is the water [[temperature]] close to the [[ocean]]'s surface. The exact meaning of ''surface'' varies according to the measurement method used, but it is between {{convert|1|mm|in|sigfig=1}} and {{convert|20|m|ft|sigfig=1}} below the [[sea]] surface. [[Air mass]]es in the [[Atmosphere of Earth|Earth's atmosphere]] are highly modified by sea surface temperatures within a short distance of the shore. Localized areas of heavy [[snow]] can form in [[rainband|bands]] downwind of warm water bodies within an otherwise cold air mass. Warm sea surface temperatures are known to be a cause of [[tropical cyclogenesis]] over the [[Earth]]'s oceans. Tropical cyclones can also cause a cool wake, due to turbulent mixing of the upper {{convert|30|m|ft|sigfig=1}} of the ocean. SST changes diurnally, like the air above it, but to a lesser degree. There is less SST variation on breezy days than on calm days. In addition, [[ocean current]]s such as the [[Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation]] (AMO), can effect SST's on multi-decadal time scales,{{cite journal|url=http://phys.org/news/2015-05-global-climate-verge-multi-decadal.html|doi=10.1038/nature14491|authors=Gerard D. McCarthy, Ivan D. Haigh, Joël J.M. Hirschi, Jeremy P. Grist & David A. Smeed|date=27 May 2015|journal=Nature|title=Ocean impact on decadal Atlantic climate variability revealed by sea-level observations|bibcode = 2015Natur.521..508M|volume=521|pages=508–510|pmid=26017453}} a major impact results from the global [[thermohaline]] circulation, which affects average SST significantly throughout most of the world's oceans. '''Ocean temperature''' is related to [[ocean heat content]], an important topic in the debate over [[global warming]]. Coastal SSTs can cause offshore winds to generate [[upwelling]], which can significantly cool or warm nearby landmasses, but shallower waters over a [[continental shelf]] are often warmer. Onshore winds can cause a considerable warm-up even in areas where upwelling is fairly constant, such as the northwest coast of [[South America]]. Its values are important within [[numerical weather prediction]] as the SST influences the atmosphere above, such as in the formation of [[sea breeze]]s and [[advection fog#Types|sea fog]]. It is also used to calibrate measurements from [[weather satellite]]s. ==Measurement== [[File:MODIS and AIRS SST comp fig2.i.jpg|right|thumb|Temperature profile of the surface layer of the ocean (a) at night and (b) during the day]] There are a variety of techniques for measuring this parameter that can potentially yield different results because different things are actually being measured. Away from the immediate sea surface, general temperature measurements are accompanied by a reference to the specific depth of measurement. This is because of significant differences encountered between measurements made at different depths, especially during the daytime when low wind speed and high sunshine conditions may lead to the formation of a warm layer at the ocean's surface and strong vertical temperature gradients (a diurnal [[thermocline]]). Sea surface temperature measurements are confined to the top portion of the ocean, known as the near-surface layer.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=tZary8a4HMwC&dq=ocean+layers+book&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=ocean%20layers%20book&f=false|page=xi|author1=Alexander Soloviev |author2=Roger Lukas |title=The near-surface layer of the ocean: structure, dynamics and applications|isbn=978-1-4020-4052-8|year=2006|publisher=シュプリンガー・ジャパン株式会社|accessdate=2011-02-10}} ===Thermometers=== SST was one of the first oceanographic variables to be measured. [[Benjamin Franklin]] suspended a [[mercury thermometer]] from a ship while travelling between the [[United States]] and [[Europe]] in his survey of the [[Gulf stream]] in the late eighteenth century. SST was later measured by dipping a [[thermometer]] into a bucket of water that was manually drawn from the sea surface. The first automated technique for determining SST was accomplished by measuring the temperature of water in the intake port of large ships, which was underway by 1963. These observations have a warm bias of around {{convert|0.6|C-change|F-change|sigfig=1}} due to the heat of the engine room.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=A6ew-bJDIDIC&pg=PA24&dq=measurement+of+sea+surface+temperature+bucket+of+water+book#v=onepage&q=measurement%20of%20sea%20surface%20temperature%20bucket%20of%20water%20book&f=false|pages=24–25|title=Data analysis methods in physical oceanography|author1=William J. Emery |author2=Richard E. Thomson |year=2001|accessdate=2011-01-09|isbn=978-0-444-50757-0|publisher=Gulf Professional Publishing}} This bias has led to changes in the perception of [[global warming]] since 2000.{{cite journal|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn19772-ships-and-buoys-made-global-warming-look-slower-.html|journal=New Scientist|author=Michael Marshall|date=2010-11-16|accessdate=2011-01-29|title=Ships and buoys made global warming look slower}} Fixed [[weather buoy]]s measure the water temperature at a depth of {{convert|3|m|ft}}. Measurements of SST have had inconsistencies over the last 130 years due to the way they were taken. In the nineteenth century, measurements were taken in a bucket off of a ship. However, there was a slight variation in temperature because of the differences in buckets. Samples were collected in either a wood or an uninsulated canvas bucket, but the canvas bucket cooled quicker than the wood bucket. The sudden change in temperature between 1940 and 1941 was the result of an undocumented change in procedure. The samples were taken near the engine intake because it was too dangerous to use lights to take measurements over the side of the ship at night.{{cite book|last=Burroughs|first=William James|title=Climate change : a multidisciplinary approach|year=2007|publisher=Cambridge Univ. Press|location=Cambridge [u.a.]|isbn=9780521690331|edition=2.}} Many different drifting buoys exist around the world that vary in design, and the location of reliable temperature sensors varies. These measurements are beamed to satellites for automated and immediate data distribution.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=hH2NkL_318wC&pg=PA263&dq=sea+surface+temperature+forecasting+numerical+weather+prediction+book#v=onepage&q=sea%20surface%20temperature%20forecasting%20numerical%20weather%20prediction%20book&f=false|pages=237–238|title=Oceanography from Space: Revisited|author=Vittorio Barale|year=2010|accessdate=2011-01-09|isbn=978-90-481-8680-8|publisher=Springer}} A large network of coastal buoys in U.S. waters is maintained by the [[National Data Buoy Center]] (NDBC).{{cite book|page=11|title=The meteorological buoy and coastal marine automated network for the United States|author=Lance F. Bosart, William A. Sprigg, National Research Council|publisher=National Academies Press|year=1998|isbn=978-0-309-06088-2}} Between 1985 and 1994, an extensive array of moored and drifting buoys was deployed across the equatorial Pacific Ocean designed to help monitor and predict the [[El Niño-Southern Oscillation#Effects of ENSO's warm phase (El Niño)|El Niño]] phenomenon.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=DO5K1NK_ZewC&pg=PA62&dq=1990+TOGA+ocean+buoy+network+Pacific+ocean+book#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Global energy and water cycles|author1=K. A. Browning |author2=Robert J. Gurney |page=62|accessdate=2011-01-09|year=1999|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=978-0-521-56057-3}} ===Weather satellites=== {{See also|Weather satellite}} [[File:MODIS sst.png|thumb|2003–2011 SST based on [[Moderate-Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer|MODIS]] Aqua data.]] Weather satellites have been available to determine sea surface temperature information since 1967, with the first global composites created during 1970.{{cite journal|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/100/mwr-100-01-0010.pdf|title=Global Sea-Surface Temperature Distribution Determined From an Environmental Satellite|author=P. Krishna Rao, W. L. Smith, and R. Koffler|pages=10–14|journal=[[Monthly Weather Review]]|volume=100|date=January 1972|accessdate=2011-01-09|issue=1|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(1972)100<0010:GSTDDF>2.3.CO;2|bibcode = 1972MWRv..100...10K }} Since 1982,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=qzYrAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA2&dq=automated+sea+surface+temperature+measurement+ship+book#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=2|author=National Research Council (U.S.). NII 2000 Steering Committee|title=The unpredictable certainty: information infrastructure through 2000; white papers|publisher=National Academies|year=1997|accessdate=2011-01-09}} [[satellite]]s have been increasingly utilized to measure SST and have allowed its [[Spatial variability|spatial]] and [[time|temporal]] variation to be viewed more fully. Satellite measurements of SST are in reasonable agreement with [[in situ]] temperature measurements.{{cite journal|url=http://ecco2.jpl.nasa.gov/data2/data/sst/Liming/LLi_output/References/SST_IR_insitu_a.pdf|journal=[[Journal of Geophysical Research]]|date=2001-02-15|accessdate=2011-01-09|volume=106|author1=W. J. Emery|author2=D. J. Baldwin|author3=Peter Schlüssel|author4=R. W. Reynolds|last-author-amp=yes|title=Accuracy of in situ sea surface temperatures used to calibrate infrared satellite measurements|page=2387|issue=C2|bibcode=2001JGR...106.2387E|doi=10.1029/2000JC000246|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721051024/http://ecco2.jpl.nasa.gov/data2/data/sst/Liming/LLi_output/References/SST_IR_insitu_a.pdf|archivedate=2011-07-21|df=}} The satellite measurement is made by sensing the ocean [[radiation]] in two or more wavelengths within the [[infrared]] part of the [[electromagnetic spectrum]] or other parts of the spectrum which can then be empirically related to SST.{{cite web|url=http://www2.hawaii.edu/~jmaurer/sst/|title=Infrared and microwave remote sensing of sea surface temperature (SST)|author=John Maurer|date=October 2002|publisher=[[University of Hawai'i]]|accessdate=2011-01-09}} These wavelengths are chosen because they are: # within the peak of the [[blackbody radiation]] expected from the Earth,{{cite journal|url=http://www.wamis.org/agm/pubs/agm8/Paper-4.pdf|page=73|journal=Satellite Remote Sensing and GIS Applications in Agricultural Meteorology|title=Meteorological Satellites|author=C. M. Kishtawal|date=2005-08-06|accessdate=2011-01-27}} and # able to transmit adequately well through the [[Earth's atmosphere|atmosphere]]{{cite journal|journal=New Scientist|date=1971-09-16|title=Mapping the Atmosphere From Space|author= Robert Harwood|page=623|volume=51|issue=769}} The satellite-measured SST provides both a [[synoptic scale|synoptic view]] of the ocean and a high frequency of repeat views,{{cite book|page=510|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Y0iX2z48qkUC&pg=PA509&lpg=PA509&dq=infrared+wavelengths+satellite+chosen+temperature+book#v=onepage&q=infrared%20wavelengths%20satellite%20chosen%20temperature%20book&f=false|author1=David E. Alexander |author2=Rhodes Whitmore Fairbridge |title=Encyclopedia of environmental science|accessdate=2011-01-27|year=1999|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-0-412-74050-3}} allowing the examination of basin-wide upper [[ocean]] dynamics not possible with ships or buoys. [http://www.nasa.gov/ NASA's] (National Aeronautic and Space Administration) [http://modis.gsfc.nasa.gov/ Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS)] SST satellites have been providing global SST data since 2000, available with a one-day lag. NOAA's [http://www.goes.noaa.gov/ GOES (Geostationary Orbiting Earth Satellites)] satellites are [[geostationary orbit|geo-stationary]] above the Western Hemisphere which enables to them to deliver SST data on an hourly basis with only a few hours of lag time. There are several difficulties with satellite-based absolute SST measurements. First, in infrared remote sensing methodology the radiation emanates from the [[Sea surface microlayer|top "skin" of the ocean]], approximately the top 0.01 [[millimetre|mm]] or less, which may not represent the [[bulk temperature]] of the upper meter of ocean due primarily to effects of solar surface heating during the daytime, reflected radiation, as well as sensible heat loss and surface evaporation. All these factors make it somewhat difficult to compare satellite data to measurements from buoys or shipboard methods, complicating ground truth efforts.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=jk1fIo51uwMC&pg=PA278&dq=measurement+of+sea+surface+temperature+book#v=onepage&q=measurement%20of%20sea%20surface%20temperature%20book&f=false|page=279|author=Ian Stuart Robinson|title=Measuring the oceans from space: the principles and methods of satellite oceanography|publisher=Springer|year=2004|accessdate=2011-01-09|isbn=978-3-540-42647-9}} Secondly, the satellite cannot look through clouds, creating a cool bias in satellite-derived SSTs within cloudy areas. However, passive microwave techniques can accurately measure SST and penetrate cloud cover. Within atmospheric sounder channels on [[weather satellite]]s, which peak just above the ocean's surface, knowledge of the sea surface temperature is important to their calibration. ==Local variation== {{See also|Upwelling}} The SST has a [[Diurnal cycle|diurnal range]], just like the Earth's atmosphere above, though to a lesser degree due to its greater specific heat.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=WdPg_1aTtr8C&pg=PA84&lpg=PA84&dq=water+higher+specific+heat+than+air+book#v=onepage&q=water%20higher%20specific%20heat%20than%20air%20book&f=false|page=84|author=John Siegenthaler|title=Modern hydronic heating for residential and light commercial buildings|year=2003|accessdate=2011-01-09|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=978-0-7668-1637-4}} On calm days, the temperature can vary by {{convert|6|C-change|F-change|sigfig=1}}. The temperature of the ocean at depth lags the Earth's atmosphere temperature by 15 days per {{convert|10|m|ft}}, which means for locations like the [[Aral Sea]], temperatures near its bottom reach a maximum in December and a minimum in May and June.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Z-LxfJVFclgC&pg=PA27&dq=sea+surface+temperature+notation+depth+book#v=onepage&q=sea%20surface%20temperature%20notation%20depth%20book&f=false|title=Physical oceanography of the dying Aral Sea|author=Peter O. Zavialov|page=27|year=2005|isbn=978-3-540-22891-2|publisher=シュプリンガー・ジャパン株式会社|accessdate=2011-01-09}} Near the coastline, offshore winds move the warm waters near the surface offshore, and replace them with cooler water from below in the process known as [[Ekman transport]]. This pattern increases nutrients for marine life in the region.{{cite web | title =Envisat watches for La Niña | publisher =BNSC via the Internet Wayback Machine | date =2008-04-24 | url =http://www.bnsc.gov.uk/content.aspx?nid=5989 | accessdate =2011-01-09 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080424113710/http://www.bnsc.gov.uk/content.aspx?nid=5989 |archivedate = 2008-04-24}} Offshore [[river delta]]s, freshwater flows over the top of the denser seawater, which allows it to heat faster due to limited vertical mixing.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=OeZ4e5MwRigC&pg=PA258&dq=upwelling+offshore+wind+sea+surface+temperature+book#v=onepage&q=upwelling%20offshore%20wind%20sea%20surface%20temperature%20book&f=false|page=258|title=State and evolution of the Baltic Sea, 1952–2005: a detailed 50-year survey of meteorology and climate, physics, chemistry, biology, and marine environment|year=2008|accessdate=2011-01-09|publisher=John Wiley and Sons|isbn=978-0-471-97968-5|author1=Rainer Feistel |author2=Günther Nausch |author3=Norbert Wasmund }} Remotely sensed SST can be used to detect the surface temperature signature due to [[tropical cyclone]]s. In general, an SST cooling is observed after the passing of a hurricane primarily as the result of mixed layer deepening and surface heat losses.{{cite web|author=Earth Observatory |url=http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/Newsroom/NewImages/images.php3?img_id=17164 |title=Passing of Hurricanes Cools Entire Gulf |year=2005 |accessdate=2006-04-26 |publisher=[[NASA|National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060930235454/http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/Newsroom/NewImages/images.php3?img_id=17164 |archivedate=2006-09-30 |df= }} In the wake of several day long [[Mineral dust#Saharan dust|Saharan dust]] outbreaks across the adjacent northern Atlantic Ocean, sea surface temperatures are reduced 0.2 C to 0.4 C (0.3 to 0.7 F).{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=b09YTtIW3f4C&pg=PA72&dq=NASA+MODIS+sea+surface+temperature+data+lag+time#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Impact of Saharan Dust on the North Atlantic Circulation|author=Nidia Martínez Avellaneda|page=72|accessdate=2011-01-27|year=2010|publisher=GRIN Verlag|isbn=978-3-640-55639-7}} Other sources of short-term SST fluctuation include [[extratropical cyclone]]s, rapid influxes of [[glacier|glacial]] fresh water{{cite journal|last=Boyle|first=Edward A.|author2=Lloyd Keigwin |title=North Atlantic thermohaline circulation during the past 20,000 years linked to high-latitude surface temperature|journal=Nature|date=5 November 1987|volume=330|issue=6143|pages=35–40|url=http://www.whoi.edu/cms/files/Boyle(1987)Nature330_35_52423.pdf|accessdate=10 February 2011|doi=10.1038/330035a0|bibcode = 1987Natur.330...35B }} and concentrated [[phytoplankton]] blooms{{cite journal|last=Beaugrand|first=Grégory|author2=Keith M. Brander |author3=J. Alistair Lindley |author4=Sami Souissi |author5=Philip C. Reid |title=Plankton effect on cod recruitment in the North Sea|journal=Nature|date=11 December 2003|volume=426|pages=661–664|doi=10.1038/nature02164|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v426/n6967/abs/nature02164.html|accessdate=10 February 2011|issue=6967|pmid=14668864|bibcode = 2003Natur.426..661B }} due to seasonal cycles or agricultural run-off.{{cite journal|last=Beman|first=J. Michael |author2=Kevin R. Arrigo |author3=Pamela A. Matson|title=Agricultural runoff fuels large phytoplankton blooms in vulnerable areas of the ocean|journal=Nature|date=10 March 2005|volume=434|pages=211–214|doi=10.1038/nature03370|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v434/n7030/abs/nature03370.html|accessdate=10 February 2011|issue=7030|pmid=15758999|bibcode = 2005Natur.434..211M }} ===Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation=== The [[Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation]] (AMO) is important for how external forcings are linked with North Atlantic SSTs.{{cite journal|url=http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2014/140225/ncomms4323/full/ncomms4323.html|doi=10.1038/ncomms4323|title=Evidence for external forcing of the Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation since termination of the Little Ice Age|date=25 February 2014|authors=Mads Faurschou Knudsen, Bo Holm Jacobsen, Marit-Solveig Seidenkrantz & Jesper Olsen|journal=Nature|bibcode = 2014NatCo...5E3323K|volume=5|pmid=24567051|pmc=3948066}} ==Regional variation== [[File:1997 El Nino TOPEX.jpg|thumb|200px|right|The 1997 El Niño observed by [[TOPEX/Poseidon]]. The white areas off the tropical coasts of South and North America indicate the pool of warm water.{{cite web | url = http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/releases/97/elninoup.html | title =Independent NASA Satellite Measurements Confirm El Niño is Back and Strong | publisher = NASA/JPL}}]] {{Main article|El Niño-Southern Oscillation}} El Niño is defined by prolonged differences in Pacific Ocean surface temperatures when compared with the average value. The accepted definition is a warming or cooling of at least 0.5 °C (0.9 °F) averaged over the east-central tropical Pacific Ocean. Typically, this anomaly happens at irregular intervals of 2–7 years and lasts nine months to two years.{{cite web|url=http://www.cpc.noaa.gov/products/analysis_monitoring/ensostuff/ensofaq.shtml#HOWOFTEN|title=ENSO FAQ: How often do El Niño and La Niña typically occur?|accessdate=2009-07-26|date=2005-12-19|author=[[Climate Prediction Center]]|publisher=[[National Centers for Environmental Prediction]]}} The average period length is 5 years. When this warming or cooling occurs for only seven to nine months, it is classified as El Niño/La Niña "conditions"; when it occurs for more than that period, it is classified as El Niño/La Niña "episodes".{{cite web|url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/oa/climate/research/enso/?year=2009&month=6&submitted=true|title=El Niño / Southern Oscillation (ENSO) June 2009|author=[[National Climatic Data Center]]|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|date=June 2009|accessdate=2009-07-26}} The sign of an El Niño in the sea surface temperature pattern is when warm water spreads from the west Pacific and the [[Indian Ocean]] to the east Pacific. It takes the rain with it, causing extensive drought in the western Pacific and rainfall in the normally dry eastern Pacific. El Niño's warm rush of nutrient-poor tropical water, heated by its eastward passage in the Equatorial Current, replaces the cold, nutrient-rich surface water of the [[Humboldt Current]]. When El Niño conditions last for many months, extensive ocean warming and the reduction in Easterly Trade winds limits upwelling of cold nutrient-rich deep water and its economic impact to local fishing for an international market can be serious.{{cite web|url=http://ww2010.atmos.uiuc.edu/(Gh)/guides/mtr/eln/home.rxml|title=El Niño|date=1998-04-28|accessdate=2009-07-17|author=WW2010|publisher=University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign}} ==Importance to the Earth's atmosphere== [[File:Snow Clouds in Korea.jpg|thumb|right|Sea-effect snow bands near the [[Korean Peninsula]]]] {{See also|Air mass|Numerical weather prediction|Precipitation (meteorology)|Effects of global warming on oceans}} Sea surface temperature affects the behavior of the [[Earth's atmosphere]] above, so their initialization into [[atmospheric model]]s is important. While sea surface temperature is important for [[tropical cyclogenesis]], it is also important in determining the formation of sea fog and sea breezes.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=hH2NkL_318wC&pg=PA263&dq=sea+surface+temperature+forecasting+numerical+weather+prediction+book#v=onepage&q=sea%20surface%20temperature%20forecasting%20numerical%20weather%20prediction%20book&f=false|page=263|title=Oceanography from Space: Revisited|author=Vittorio Barale|year=2010|accessdate=2011-01-09|isbn=978-90-481-8680-8|publisher=Springer}} Heat from underlying warmer waters can significantly modify an air mass over distances as short as {{convert|35|km|mi}} to {{convert|40|km|mi}}.{{cite journal|url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/fm26377722407422/|author=Jun Inoue, Masayuki Kawashima, Yasushi Fujiyoshi and Masaaki Wakatsuchi|title=Aircraft Observations of Air-mass Modification Over the Sea of Okhotsk during Sea-ice Growth|issue=1|date=October 2005|doi=10.1007/s10546-004-3407-y|pages=111–129|issn=0006-8314|volume=117| journal=Boundary-Layer Meteorology|bibcode = 2005BoLMe.117..111I }} For example, southwest of Northern Hemisphere [[extratropical cyclone]]s, curved cyclonic flow bringing cold air across relatively warm water bodies can lead to narrow [[lake-effect snow]] (or sea effect) bands. Those bands bring strong localized [[precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]], often in the form of [[snow]], since large water bodies such as lakes efficiently store heat that results in significant temperature differences—larger than {{convert|13|C-change|F-change|sigfig=2}}—between the water surface and the air above.{{cite news|author=B. Geerts |year=1998|url=http://www-das.uwyo.edu/~geerts/cwx/notes/chap10/lake_effect_snow.html |title=Lake Effect Snow.| accessdate= 2008-12-24|publisher=[[University of Wyoming]]}} Because of this temperature difference, warmth and moisture are transported upward, condensing into vertically oriented clouds which produce snow showers. The temperature decrease with height and cloud depth are directly affected by both the water temperature and the large-scale environment. The stronger the temperature decrease with height, the taller the clouds get, and the greater the precipitation rate becomes.{{cite web|url=http://www.comet.ucar.edu/class/smfaculty/byrd/sld010.htm |publisher=[[University Corporation for Atmospheric Research]] |title=Lake Effect Snow |date=1998-06-03 |accessdate=2009-07-12 |author=Greg Byrd |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090617013142/http://www.comet.ucar.edu/class/smfaculty/byrd/sld010.htm |archivedate=2009-06-17 |df= }} ===Tropical cyclones=== [[File:WorldwideTCpeaks.gif|thumb|right|Seasonal peaks of tropical cyclone activity worldwide]] [[File:Mean sst equatorial pacific.gif|thumb|right|200 px|Average equatorial Pacific temperatures]] {{Main article|Tropical cyclogenesis|Tropical cyclones and climate change}} Ocean temperature of at least 26.5[[degrees Celsius|°C]] (79.7[[degrees Fahrenheit|°F]]) spanning through at minimum a 50-[[metre]] depth is one of the precursors needed to maintain a [[tropical cyclone]] (a type of [[mesocyclone]]).{{cite web|author=[[Chris Landsea]]|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/tcfaq/A15.html|title=Subject: A15) How do tropical cyclones form?|accessdate=2011-01-27|year=2011|publisher=[[Hurricane Research Division]]}}{{cite web|last=Webster|first=PJ|title=Changes in tropical cyclone number, duration, and intensity in a warming environment|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?id=GALE%7CA136847986&v=2.1&u=mnastbens&it=r&p=PROF&sw=w&asid=335992f2037df3339c5901f7981d2045|publisher=Gale Group}} These warm waters are needed to maintain the [[Tropical cyclone#Mechanics|warm core]] that fuels tropical systems. This value is well above 16.1 °C (60.9 °F), the long term global average surface temperature of the oceans.{{Cite web| author = Matt Menne | publisher = [[National Climatic Data Center]] | url = http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/cmb-faq/anomalies.php#mean | title = Global Long-term Mean Land and Sea Surface Temperatures | date = March 15, 2000 | accessdate = 2006-10-19}} However, this requirement can be considered only a general baseline because it assumes that the ambient atmospheric environment surrounding an area of disturbed weather presents average conditions. Tropical cyclones have intensified when SSTs were slightly below this standard temperature. Tropical cyclones are known to form even when normal conditions are not met. For example, cooler air temperatures at a higher altitude (e.g., at the 500 [[hPa]] level, or 5.9 km) can lead to tropical cyclogenesis at lower water temperatures, as a certain [[lapse rate]] is required to force the atmosphere to be [[Baroclinic instability|unstable]] enough for convection. In a moist atmosphere, this lapse rate is 6.5 °C/km, while in an atmosphere with less than 100% [[relative humidity]], the required lapse rate is 9.8 °C/km.{{cite web|year=2000|last=Kushnir|first=Yochanan|title=The Climate System|url=http://eesc.columbia.edu/courses/ees/climate/lectures/atm_phys.html|publisher=[[Columbia University]]|accessdate=24 September 2010}} At the 500 hPa level, the air temperature averages −7 °C (18 °F) within the tropics, but air in the tropics is normally dry at this height, giving the air room to [[Wet-bulb temperature|wet-bulb]], or cool as it moistens, to a more favorable temperature that can then support convection. A wetbulb temperature at 500 hPa in a tropical atmosphere of {{convert|-13.2|C|F}} is required to initiate convection if the water temperature is {{convert|26.5|C|F}}, and this temperature requirement increases or decreases proportionally by 1 °C in the sea surface temperature for each 1 °C change at 500 hpa. Inside a [[cold-core low|cold cyclone]], 500 hPa temperatures can fall as low as {{convert|-30|C|F}}, which can initiate convection even in the driest atmospheres. This also explains why moisture in the mid-levels of the [[troposphere]], roughly at the 500 hPa level, is normally a requirement for development. However, when dry air is found at the same height, temperatures at 500 hPa need to be even colder as dry atmospheres require a greater lapse rate for instability than moist atmospheres.{{cite book|title=Atmospheric Science: An Introductory Survey|author1=John M. Wallace |author2=Peter V. Hobbs |lastauthoramp=yes |pages=76–77|publisher=Academic Press, Inc|year=1977}}{{Cite web| author = [[Chris Landsea]] | url = http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/climvari/index.html | title = Climate Variability of Tropical Cyclones: Past, Present and Future | year = 2000 | work = Storms | pages = 220–41 | accessdate = 2006-10-19 | publisher = [[Atlantic Oceanographic and Meteorological Laboratory]]}} At heights near the [[tropopause]], the 30-year average temperature (as measured in the period encompassing 1961 through 1990) was −77 °C (−132 °F).{{Cite web| author = Dian J. Gaffen-Seidel, Rebecca J. Ross and James K. Angell | title = Climatological characteristics of the tropical tropopause as revealed by radiosondes | url = http://www.aero.jussieu.fr/~sparc/SPARC2000_new/OralSess2/D_Gaffen/GaffenHtml/Abs_Gaffen.html | publisher = [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Air Resources Laboratory]] |date = November 2000| accessdate = 2006-10-19 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060508184913/http://www.aero.jussieu.fr/~sparc/SPARC2000_new/OralSess2/D_Gaffen/GaffenHtml/Abs_Gaffen.html |archivedate = May 8, 2006}} A recent example of a [[tropical cyclone]] that maintained itself over cooler waters was [[Hurricane Epsilon (2005)|Epsilon]] of the [[2005 Atlantic hurricane season]].{{cite web|author=Lixion Avila|date=2005-12-03|title=Hurricane Epsilon Discussion Eighteen|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2010-12-14|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2005/dis/al292005.discus.018.shtml?}} ==See also== * [[Ocean heat content]] * [[The Blob (Pacific Ocean)]] * [[Current sea level rise]] can occur during an increase of global or regional average SST * [[Halocline]] refers to a salinity difference often altered by temperature-dependent factors * [[Loop Current]], with plots of sea temperature in the [[Gulf of Mexico]] * [[Pacific Decadal Oscillation]] (PDO) * [[Plankton]], which blooms at rates dependent on sea surface temperature * [[Salinity]], which affects sea surface evaporation and thus temperature * [[Ghrsst-pp]] the Group for High Resolution SST * [[Satellite temperature measurements]] * A '''state microbe''' is a [[microorganism]] used as an official state symbol. Several [[U.S. state]]s have honored their [[Microorganism|microbial]] residents by nominating them to become official [[Lists of United States state symbols|state symbols]]. The first state to declare an Official State Microbe is [[Oregon]] which chose ''[[Saccharomyces cerevisiae]]'' (brewer's or [[baker's yeast]]) as the Official Microbe of the State of Oregon in 2013 for its significance to the [[craft beer]] industry in Oregon.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.craftbrewingbusiness.com/ingredients-supplies/oregon-first-to-name-official-state-yeast/ |title=Oregon first to name official state yeast |first= Jason |last= Morgan |date= April 8, 2013|work=Craft Brewing Business}}</ref> One of the first proponents of State Microbes was the eminent microbiologist Dr [[Moselio Schaechter]], who, in 2010, commented on Official Microbes for the American Society for Microbiology's blog "Small Things Considered"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://schaechter.asmblog.org/schaechter/2010/05/state-microbes.html|title=State Microbes|website=Small Things Considered|access-date=2018-09-16}}</ref> as well as on National Public Radio's "All Things Considered".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=126055019|title=A State Microbe For Cheese-Crazed Wisconsin?|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-09-16|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=126370268|title=No State Microbe For Wisconsin|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-09-16|language=en}}</ref>
==Wisconsin 2009: ''Lactococcus lactis'', proposed, not passed== [[File:Lactococcus lactis, scanning electron micrograph.jpg|thumb|''Lactococcus lactis'' micrograph courtesy of Kenneth Todar, PhD.|left|214x214px]] In November 2009, Assembly Bill 556 that proposed designating ''[[Lactococcus lactis]]'' as Wisconsin state microbe was introduced by [[Wisconsin State Assembly|Representative]]s [[Gary Hebl|Hebl]], [[Amy Sue Vruwink|Vruwink]], Williams, [[Sandy Pasch|Pasch]], [[Chris Danou|Danou]], and Fields; it was cosponsored by [[Lena Taylor|Senator Taylor]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://docs.legis.wisconsin.gov/2009/proposals/ab556|title=2009 Assembly Bill 556|website=docs.legis.wisconsin.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-11-20}}</ref> Although the bill passed the Assembly 56 to 41, It was not acted on by the [[Wisconsin State Senate|Senate]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/16/us/16microbe.html|title=Wisconsin Legislators Approve State Microbe|last=Davey|first=Monica|date=2010-04-15|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-11-20|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> The proposed AB 556 simply stated that ''[[Lactococcus lactis]]'' is the State Microbe and should be included in the [[Wisconsin Blue Book]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://docs.legis.wisconsin.gov/2009/related/proposals/ab556.pdf|title=2009 Assembly Bill 556|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> an almanac containing information on the state of [[Wisconsin]], published by Wisconsin’s Legislative Reference Bureau.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2017-09-17|title=Wisconsin Blue Book|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wisconsin_Blue_Book&oldid=801139687|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref>[[File:Prize winning cheese by the makers of Wisconsin Goliath Cheeses, Steves Cheese produced by Steves Cheese Co., Denmark, Wisconsin.jpg|thumb|Wisconsin is a great cheese state.|188x188px]]''Lactococcus lactis'' was proposed as the State Microbe because of its crucial contribution to the [[cheese]] industry in Wisconsin. Wisconsin is the largest cheese producer in the United States, producing 3.1 billion pounds of cheese, 26% of all cheese in the US, in more than 600 varieties (2017 data).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wmmb.com/assets/images/pdf/WisconsinDairyData.pdf|title=2017 Wisconsin Dairy Data|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> ''Lactococcus lactis'' is vital for manufacturing cheeses such as [[Cheddar cheese|Cheddar]], [[Colby cheese|Colby]], [[cottage cheese]], [[cream cheese]], [[Camembert]], [[Roquefort]], and [[Brie]], as well as other dairy products like [[Butter#Types|cultured butter]], [[buttermilk]], [[sour cream]], and [[kefir]]. It may also be used for vegetable [[fermentation]]s such as [[Pickled cucumber|cucumber pickles]] and [[sauerkraut]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://advanced.bact.wisc.edu/themicrobialworld/Lactococcus.html|title=Lactococcus lactis Wisconsin State Microbe|website=advanced.bact.wisc.edu|access-date=2017-11-20}}</ref>
==Hawai{{okina}}i 2013-14: ''Flavobacterium akiainvivens'' and/or ''Aliivibrio fischeri'', to be continued ...== [[File:Hawaiian Bobtail squid.tiff|thumb|The bobtail squid can be a home for ''Aliivibrio fischeri''|209x209px]] In January 2013, House Bill 293 was introduced by State Representative [[James Tokioka]]; the proposed bill designates ''[[Flavobacterium akiainvivens]]'' as the State Microbe of [[Hawaii|Hawai{{okina}}i]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hanahou.com/pages/magazine.asp?Action=DrawArticle&ArticleID=1253|title=Hana Hou: The Magazine of Hawaiian Airlines - Current Issue|website=www.hanahou.com|access-date=2017-11-20}}</ref> The bacterium was discovered on a decaying [[Wikstroemia oahuensis|{{okina}}ākia]] shrub by [[ Iris Kuo]], a high school student working with [[Stuart Donachie]] at the [[University of Hawaii at Manoa|University of Hawai{{okina}}i at Manoa]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cen.acs.org/articles/91/i19/Computers-Play-Super-Mario-States.html|title=Computers Play Super Mario, States Adopt Microbes {{!}} May 13, 2013 Issue - Vol. 91 Issue 19 {{!}} Chemical & Engineering News|last=Torrice|first=Michael|website=cen.acs.org|access-date=2017-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.microbiologyresearch.org/docserver/fulltext/ijsem/63/9/3280_ijs047217.pdf?expires=1511207051&id=id&accname=guest&checksum=91E6CAA72C95B5CC8D912EBA2842B88C|title=Flavobacterium akiainvivens sp. nov., from decaying wood of Wikstroemia oahuensis , Hawai'i, and emended description of the genus Flavobacterium|journal=International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology|volume=63|issue=Pt 9|pages=3280–3286|last=Kuo, Iris et al.|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=|doi=10.1099/ijs.0.047217-0|pmid=23475344|year=2013}}</ref> The Hawai{{okina}}ian context is strong here because the {{okina}}ākia shrub (''Wikstroemia oahuensis'') is native to Hawai{{okina}}i, and the microbe (''Flavobacterium akiainvivens)'' was first found in Hawai{{okina}}i. The shrub was used by ancient Hawai{{okina}}ians for medicine, textiles and for catching fish, while the microbe may have antibiotic properties.<ref name=":0" /> [[File:Aliivibrio fischeri.jpg|thumb|left|''Aliivibrio fischeri'' glowing on a petri dish]] Although it was favored by the House, the ''Flavobacterium akiainvivens'' bill failed to get a hearing in the Senate Technology and Arts Committee (TEC) and could not move forward for a Senate vote.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hawaiireporter.com/competing-to-be-hawaiis-top-microbe/|title=Competing to be Hawaii's top microbe - Hawaii Reporter|date=2014-01-28|work=Hawaii Reporter|access-date=2017-11-20|language=en-US}}</ref>[[File:Wikstroemia oahuensis var. oahuensis (5187960983).jpg|thumb|''Flavobacterium akiavivensis'' was discovered in an akai bush.|202x202px]] In February 2014, Senate Bill 3124 was introduced by Senator [[Glenn Wakai]]; the bill designates ''[[Aliivibrio fischeri]]'' as the State Microbe of Hawai{{okina}}i.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://damontucker.com/2014/02/24/bill-to-make-hawaiian-bobtail-squid-hawaiis-official-state-microbe-to-be-heard-tomorrow/|title=Bill to Make Hawaiian Bobtail Squid Hawaii’s Official State Microbe to be Heard Tomorrow|date=2014-02-25|work=Hawaii News and Island Information|access-date=2017-11-20|language=en-US}}</ref> <ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.capitol.hawaii.gov/session2014/bills/SB3124_.pdf|title=SB3124 Hawaiian Senate Bill, 2014|last=Wakai|first=Glenn|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Senator Wakai was Chairman of the Senate Technology and Arts Committee that squashed the ''Flavobacterium'' legislation. ''Aliivibrio fischeri'' was selected because it lives in a symbiotic relationship with the native [[Euprymna scolopes|Hawai{{okina}}ian bobtail squid]], in which it confers [[bioluminescence]] on the squid, enabling it to hunt at night.<ref name=":1" /> Although this is an awesome example of [[symbiosis]], political and scientific controversy erupted because even though the bobtail squid is only found in Hawai{{okina}}i, ''Aliivibrio fischeri'' can be found elsewhere.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/State-Microbe-for-Hawaii-254376537973522/|title=State Microbe for Hawaii|last=|first=|date=|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://microbewiki.kenyon.edu/index.php/Vibrio_fischeri_NEU2011|title=Vibrio fischeri NEU2011 - microbewiki|website=microbewiki.kenyon.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-11-20}}</ref>
The combined Hawai{{okina}}ian Legislature could not agree on which microbe better suited Hawai{{okina}}i, and the proposed legislation was dropped.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/04/03/official-state-bacteria_n_5080910.html|title=Hawaii, Other States Calling Dibs On Official State Bacteria|last=Cave|first=James|date=2014-04-03|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2017-11-20|language=en-US}}</ref>
Legislation proposing ''[[Flavobacterium akiainvivens]]'' as the State Microbe was re-introduced in 2017, {{See below|Hawaii 2017: Flavobacterium akiainvivens, pending|mid=y}}.
==Oregon 2013: ''Saccharomyces cerevisiae'', passed== [[File:Saccharomyces cerevisiae SEM.jpg|thumb|Saccharomyces cerevisiae (brewer's yeast) as seen in a scanning electron micrograph.|left]] [[Oregon]] was the first state to declare an Official State Microbe.[[File:MisterAlcohol Beer.png|thumb|Beer is a noteworthy product of brewer's yeast, the Official Microbe of Oregon.]] In February 2013, House Concurrent Resolution 12 (HCR-12) was introduced into the [[Oregon Legislative Assembly|Oregon legislative system]] by [[Oregon House of Representatives|Representative]] [[Mark Johnson (Oregon politician)|Mark Johnson]]; the bill designates ''[[Saccharomyces cerevisiae]]'' (brewer's yeast or bakers yeast) as the Official Microbe of the State of Oregon.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/politics/index.ssf/2013/05/oregon_could_be_first_in_natio.html|title=Oregon is first in nation with official state microbe: brewer's yeast|work=OregonLive.com|access-date=2017-11-21|language=en-US}}</ref> The bill was passed by unanimous vote in the House on April 11; it passed in the Senate by a vote of 28 to 2 on May 23. <ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://gov.oregonlive.com/bill/2013/HCR12/|title=Tracking House Concurrent Resolution 12 in the Oregon Legislature|work=Your Government :: The Oregonian|access-date=2017-11-21|language=en-US}}</ref> Cosponsors of the measure were: Representatives [[Michael Dembrow|Dembrow]], [[Mike McLane|McLane]], [[Jessica Vega Pederson|Vega Pederson]], [[Gene Whisnant|Whisnant]], [[Jennifer Williamson|Williamson]], and Senators [[Bill Hansell|Hansell]], [[Floyd Prozanski|Prozanski]], and [[Chuck Thomsen|Thomsen]].<ref name=":2" />
HCR-12 recognizes the history of ''Saccharomyces cerevisiae'' in baking and brewing, thanks to its ability to convert fermentable sugars into [[ethanol]] and [[carbon dioxide]]. Most important for Oregon is that the microbe is essential to the production of [[Alcoholic drink|alcoholic beverages]] such as [[mead]], [[wine]], [[beer]], and distilled spirits. Moreover ''Saccharomyces cerevisiae'' inspired the thriving brew culture in Oregon, making Oregon an internationally recognized hub of [[Microbrewery|craft brewing]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://olis.leg.state.or.us/liz/2013R1/Downloads/MeasureDocument/HCR12/Enrolled|title=Enrolled House Concurrent Legislation 12|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The craft brewing business brings Oregon $2.4 billion annually, thanks to brewers yeast and talented brewers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.popsci.com/science/article/2013-04/beersci-oregon-wants-name-ale-yeast-its-official-microbe|title=Ale Yeast Running For Official State Microbe Of Oregon|work=Popular Science|access-date=2017-11-28|language=en}}</ref>
==New Jersey 2017-2018: ''Streptomyces griseus'', pending== [[File:Streptomyces griseus color enhanced scanning electron micrograph..jpg|left|thumb|227x227px|''Streptomyces griseus'' shown in a color-enhanced scanning electron micrograph. Original b&w image used with permission of the Actinomycetes Society of Japan by S. Amano, S. Miyadoh & T. Shomura .]]
=== Introduction === ''Streptomyces griseus'' was chosen for the honor of becoming the New Jersey State Microbe because the organism is a New Jersey native that made unique contributions to healthcare and scientific research worldwide. A strain of ''S. griseus'' that produced the antibiotic [[streptomycin]] was discovered in New Jersey in “heavily [[manure]]d field soil” from the New Jersey Agricultural Experimental Station by [[Albert Schatz (scientist)|Albert Schatz]] in 1943.<ref>Schatz A, Bugie E, Waksman SE. (1944). "Streptomycin, a Substance Exhibiting Antibiotic Activity Against Gram-Positive and Gram-Negative Bacteria". Proceedings of the Society for Experimental Biology and Medicine. 55: 66–69.</ref> Streptomycin is noteworthy because it is: the first significant antibiotic discovered after [[penicillin]]; the first systemic [[Antibiotics|antibiotic]] discovered in America; the first antibiotic active against [[tuberculosis]]; first-line treatment for [[Plague (disease)|plague]]. Moreover, New Jersey was the home of [[Selman Waksman]], who was awarded the [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine]] for his systematic studies of antibiotic production by ''S. griseus'' and other soil microbes.<ref>''"The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1952". www.nobelprize.org. Retrieved 2017-11-16.''</ref>
=== Legislative Activity === On May 15, 2017, Senate Bill 3190 (S3190) was introduced by [[New Jersey Senate|Senator]] [[Samuel D. Thompson]] (R-12); the bill designates ''[[Streptomyces griseus]]'' as the [[New Jersey]] State Microbe, to be added to [[List of New Jersey state symbols|the state's other state symbols]]. On June 1, 2017 [[New Jersey General Assembly|Assemblywoman]] [[Annette Quijano]] (D-20) introduced Assembly Bill 4900 (A4900); the bill also designates ''S. griseus'' as the New Jersey State Microbe, and is the Assembly counterpart of S3190.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.njleg.state.nj.us/2016/Bills/A5000/4900_I1.HTM|title=A4900|website=www.njleg.state.nj.us|access-date=2017-11-28}}</ref> S3190 was referred to the Senate State Government, Wagering, Tourism & Historic Preservation Committee and A4900 was referred to the Assembly State and Local Government Committee for consideration and review.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://legiscan.com/NJ/research/A4900/2016|title=New Jersey A4900 {{!}} 2016-2017 {{!}} Regular Session|work=LegiScan|access-date=2017-11-28|language=en}}</ref> [[File:Streptomycin gif.gif|thumb|The potent antibiotic streptomycin is produced by Streptomyces griseus.]] On December 11, 2017 (the birthday of Dr [[Robert Koch]]) S3190, the bill that designates ''S. griseus'' as the New Jersey State Microbe, was '''unanimously approved''' by the NJ Senate State Government. Wagering, Tourism & Historic Preservation Committee. Committee members were Senators [[Samuel D. Thompson|Samuel Thompson]] (sponsor), [[James Beach]] (chair) [[Shirley Turner]] (vice chair), and [[Patrick J. Diegnan|Patrick Diegnan]]. Speaking on behalf of the State Microbe were Drs John Warhol, Douglas Eveleigh<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dbm.rutgers.edu/pages/Douglas_Eveleigh.html|title=Douglas E. Eveleigh Department of Biochemistry and Microbiology at Rutgers SEBS|website=dbm.rutgers.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-12-12}}</ref>, and Max Haggblom<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dbm.rutgers.edu/pages/Max_Haggblom.html|title=Max Häggblom Department of Biochemistry and Microbiology at Rutgers SEBS|website=dbm.rutgers.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-12-12}}</ref>.
On January 8, 2018 the '''full New Jersey Senate unanimously approved''' (38 to 0) S3190 to designate ''S. griseus'' as the New Jersey State Microbe.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.njleg.state.nj.us/bills/BillView.asp?BillNumber=S3190|title=New Jersey Legislature - Bills|website=www.njleg.state.nj.us|language=en|access-date=2018-01-09}}</ref> The bill was cosponsored by Senator [[Fred H. Madden]] (D-4).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://legiscan.com/NJ/sponsors/S3190/2016|title=New Jersey S3190 {{!}} 2016-2017 {{!}} Regular Session|work=LegiScan|access-date=2018-02-21|language=en}}</ref> The Assembly did not act on its version of the State Microbe legislation.
State Microbe legislation was reintroduced in the New Jersey Senate on February 5, 2018 by Senator Samuel Thompson (R-12); the bill number is S1729.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://legiscan.com/NJ/bill/S1729/2018|title=New Jersey S1729 {{!}} 2018-2019 {{!}} Regular Session|work=LegiScan|access-date=2018-03-02|language=en}}</ref> The bill will be reviewed by the NJ Senate State Government, Wagering, Tourism & Historic Preservation Committee whose members are Senators [[Samuel D. Thompson|Samuel Thompson]], [[James Beach]] (chair) [[Shirley Turner]] (vice chair), [[Chris A. Brown]], and [[Nilsa Cruz-Perez]]. The new senate bill has bipartisan support and is cosponsored by Senator [[Patrick J. Diegnan|Patrick Diegnan]] (D-18) and Senator Vin Gopal (D-11).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://legiscan.com/NJ/bill/S1729/2018|title=New Jersey S1729 {{!}} 2018-2019 {{!}} Regular Session|work=LegiScan|access-date=2018-04-09|language=en}}</ref>
Similar legislation was reintroduced in the New Jersey Assembly on March 12, 2018; the bill number is A3650. The legislation is sponsored by Assemblywoman Annette Quijano (D-20), ASW Patricia Jones (D-5), Assemblyman [[Arthur Barclay (American politician)|Arthur Barclay]] (D-5), ASM Eric Houghtaling (D-11), and ASW Joann Downey (D-11).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://legiscan.com/NJ/bill/A3650/2018|title=New Jersey A3650 {{!}} 2018-2019 {{!}} Regular Session|work=LegiScan|access-date=2018-04-13|language=en}}</ref> Assemblyman [[Ronald S. Dancer|Ronald Dancer]] (R-12) also signed on as a cosponsor.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://legiscan.com/NJ/bill/A3650/2018|title=New Jersey A3650 {{!}} 2018-2019 {{!}} Regular Session|work=LegiScan|access-date=2018-06-22|language=en}}</ref> The bill will be reviewed by the Assembly Science, Innovation and Technology Committee, whose members are ASM [[Andrew Zwicker]], PhD (D-16), ASM James Kennedy (D-22), ASM [[Herb Conaway]], MD (D-7), ASW [[BettyLou DeCroce]] (R-26), ASM Christopher DePhillips (R-40), ASM Time Eustace, DC (D-38), and ASW Brittnee Timberlake (D-34).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://legiscan.com/NJ/bill/A3650/2018|title=New Jersey A3650 {{!}} 2018-2019 {{!}} Regular Session|work=LegiScan|access-date=2018-04-09|language=en}}</ref>
On June 14, 2018 Senate Bill S1729 was '''unanimously approved''' by the NJ Senate State Government, Wagering, Tourism & Historic Preservation Committee.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://legiscan.com/NJ/bill/S1729/2018|title=New Jersey S1729 {{!}} 2018-2019 {{!}} Regular Session|work=LegiScan|access-date=2018-06-22|language=en}}</ref>
On July 27, 2018 Senate Bill S1729 was '''unanimously approved''' (33 to 0) by the full New Jersey Senate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.njleg.state.nj.us/bills/BillView.asp?BillNumber=S1729|title=New Jersey Legislature - Bills|website=www.njleg.state.nj.us|language=en|access-date=2018-07-31}}</ref> From the well of the Senate, Senator Thompson kindly acknowledged the efforts of State Microbe advocates John Warhol, Douglas Eveleigh, Jeff Boyd, and Jessica Lisa.
On September 17, 2018 Assembly Bill A3650 was '''unanimously approved''' by the Assembly Science, Innovation, and Technology Committee.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.njleg.state.nj.us/bills/BillView.asp?BillNumber=A3650|title=New Jersey Legislature - Bills|website=www.njleg.state.nj.us|language=en|access-date=2018-09-19}}</ref> Testifying on behalf of the State Microbe were Drs John Warhol, Douglas Eveleigh, and Jeff Boyd; their testimony can be heard on the [https://www.njleg.state.nj.us/bills/BillView.asp?BillNumber=A3650 New Jersey Legislature Media site]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.njleg.state.nj.us/bills/BillView.asp?BillNumber=A3650|title=New Jersey Legislature - Bills|website=www.njleg.state.nj.us|language=en|access-date=2018-09-19}}</ref> starting at 27 minutes. Asm Tim Eustace on The Committee was replaced by Assemblywoman Linda S Carter.
=== Education Activity === The Rutgers University [[Rutgers School of Environmental and Biological Sciences|School of Environmental and Biological Science]] (SEBS) Department of Biochemistry and Microbiology has provided a web page since 2010 on which people can vote for one of three excellent choices for the New Jersey State Microbe. The candidates have been ''[[Acidithiobacillus thiooxidans]]'' (discovered in NJ, 1922), ''[[Azotobacter vinelandii]]'' (discovered in [[Vineland nj|Vineland, NJ]], 1903), and ''Streptomyces griseus'' ([[New Brunswick, NJ]] is home of the streptomycin-producing strain).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dbm.rutgers.edu/stateMicrobe.php|title=Vote for State Microbe {{!}} Department of Microbiology and Biochemistry at the Rutgers School of Environmental and Biological Sciences|website=dbm.rutgers.edu|access-date=2018-03-16}}</ref> ''S. griseus'' has been the winning microbe by a 3 to 1 margin. The Department of Biochemistry and Microbiology has also been actively involved in public education and outreach at annual Rutgers Day events.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rutgersday.rutgers.edu/content/passion-puddle-area|title=Passion Puddle Area {{!}} Rutgers Day|website=rutgersday.rutgers.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-06-22}}</ref> In 2018, they received hundreds of signatures on a petition urging legislators to recognize ''S. griseus'' as the State Microbe. The microbiology community, both within and outside of NJ, has been an advocate for the State Microbe, actively submitting letters of endorsement to the New Jersey Legislature.
The New Jersey State Microbe was the subject of a presentation by John Warhol at the 2018 [[Rutgers University]] Microbiology Symposium,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dbm.rutgers.edu/MicrobioSymPrgrm2018.pdf|title=Rutgers Microbiology Symposium 2018|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> video of the presentation is available [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Iei0-tH03aI here]. Dr Warhol also spoke about the New Jersey State Microbe at the Theobald Smith Society (NJ Chapter of the American Society for Microbiology) Meeting in Miniature at [[Seton Hall University]] in April 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.shu.edu/arts-sciences/news/shu-to-host-theobald-smith-society-meeting.cfm|title=Seton Hall University to Host the Theobald Smith Society Meeting in Miniature - Seton Hall University|website=www.shu.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-06-22}}</ref>
The New Jersey State Microbe was the subject of a Science Cafe, titled The New Jersey State Microbe and You-- Perfect Together! held at the New Jersey Institute for Food, Nutrition, and Health on March 1. Presenters were Max Haggblom, Douglas Eveleigh, and John Warhol.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://microminutes.tumblr.com/image/171385435429|title=Micro Minutes! : Photo|website=microminutes.tumblr.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-02}}</ref>
In April 2018, Dr Jeffrey Boyd spoke to students and teachers at the Bartle Elementary School in Highland Park, firing up their enthusiasm for microbial life in general and ''S. griseus'' in particular. The students were taught about microbiology, antibiotics, the interaction of science and public service, and how to contact their state legislators.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://microminutes.tumblr.com/post/173991310639/microbial-school-outreach-rutgers-professor-dr|title=Micro Minutes!, Microbial School Outreach Rutgers Professor Dr…|website=Micro Minutes!|language=en|access-date=2018-06-28}}</ref> In May, John Warhol introduced the topic of microbiology and the State Microbe to students at the Indian Hill School in Holmdel.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://microminutes.tumblr.com/post/175327698532/talking-about-microbes-in-school-i-had-the|title=Micro Minutes!, Talking about Microbes in School I had the…|website=Micro Minutes!|language=en|access-date=2018-06-28}}</ref>
A scientific paper on the political and social process of designating an official state microbe was presented at Microbe 2018, the annual meeting of the American Society for Microbiology.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abstractsonline.com/pp8/#!/4623/presentation/6277|title=Program Planner|website=www.abstractsonline.com|access-date=2018-06-22}}</ref> Titled "How to Get Your Own Official State Microbe" the presentation stressed the importance of clear communication and legislator contact by academic, industrial, and student supporters. The authors were Max Haggblom, Douglas Eveleigh, and John Warhol.
In mid-September, John Warhol gave a public presentation on the New Jersey State Microbe and science communication at the Middletown, NJ Public Library.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://microminutes.tumblr.com/post/179828059459/microbe-talk-at-the-library-this-was-a-lot-of|title=Micro Minutes!, Microbe Talk at The Library. This was a lot of...|website=Micro Minutes!|language=en|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mtpl.evanced.info/signup/Calendar|title=Middletown Library Presentation Calendar|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
An update on the New Jersey State Microbe project was given to students and faculty at the University of the Sciences in Philadelphia in October 2018 by John Warhol, as part of a seminar on science communication.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://microminutes.tumblr.com/post/179462955804/university-of-the-sciences-presentation-wow-my|title=Micro Minutes!, University of the Sciences Presentation Wow, my...|website=Micro Minutes!|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>
In November 2018, the New Jersey Historical Commission Forum on New Jersey History at Monmouth University was the venue for two presentations on the State Microbe. The first was titled "An Official New Jersey State Microbe! Streptomyces griseus" and the second was "The 75th Anniversary of the Discovery of Streptomycin - 2019". Authors of the presentations were Douglas Eveleigh, Jeff Boyd, Max Haagblom, Jessica Lisa, and John Warhol.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://microminutes.tumblr.com/post/179797494569/microbiology-at-the-nj-historical-commission-forum|title=Micro Minutes!, Microbiology at the NJ Historical Commission Forum...|website=Micro Minutes!|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nj.gov/state/historical/dos_his_forum-2018-1102.html|title=New Jersey Department of State - Historical Commission - Grants and Prizes|website=nj.gov|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>
In early November 2018, Rutgers University launched a web page recognizing the Selman Waksman Museum at the School of Environmental and Biological Sciences. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://waksmanmuseum.rutgers.edu/|title=Waksman Museum at Rutgers SEBS|website=waksmanmuseum.rutgers.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref> The museum is housed in Dr Waksman's former laboratory space in Martin Hall. The museum was developed under the leadership of Douglas Eveleigh with grant support from the US Department of Agriculture. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://portal.nifa.usda.gov/web/crisprojectpages/0205929-recognizing-the-historic-development-of-american-microbiology-and-in-particular-soil-microbiology-from-george-washington-to-selman-waksman.html|title=RECOGNIZING THE HISTORIC DEVELOPMENT OF AMERICAN MICROBIOLOGY AND IN PARTICULAR SOIL MICROBIOLOGY FROM GEORGE WASHINGTON TO SELMAN WAKSMAN - RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY|website=portal.nifa.usda.gov|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref>
=== Press and Media Coverage === Following the Senate vote, The New Jersey State Microbe was the subject of local, national, and international media attention. Streaming audio and video interviews were broadcast or posted with Drs Eveleigh, Boyd, Warhol, and Haggblom on [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A2wn0P3V9F0 CBS news] , [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1k0oToU_fZ8 News 12 New Jersey] , [https://www.npr.org/2018/08/07/636423606/n-j-legislature-close-to-giving-garden-state-an-official-microbe-with-local-root National Public Radio] , [https://www.asm.org/index.php/podcasts/twim/item/7394-dr-warhol-s-periodic-table-of-microbes-twim-181 This Week In Microbiology] , and [https://kywnewsradio.radio.com/articles/news/seriously-new-jersey-poised-name-official-state-microbe KYWNews Radio].<ref>{{Citation|last=CBS New York|title=This Bacteria Could Become NJ's Official State Microbe|date=2018-07-27|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A2wn0P3V9F0|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=WarholScience|title=News 12 NJ State Microbe|date=2018-08-03|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1k0oToU_fZ8|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/08/07/636423606/n-j-legislature-close-to-giving-garden-state-an-official-microbe-with-local-root|title=N.J. Legislature Close To Giving Garden State An Official Microbe With Local Roots|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-09-06|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.asm.org/index.php/podcasts/twim/item/7394-dr-warhol-s-periodic-table-of-microbes-twim-181|title=Dr. Warhol’s Periodic Table of Microbes - TWiM 181|last=Racaniello|first=Vincent|access-date=2018-09-06|language=en-gb}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://kywnewsradio.radio.com/articles/news/seriously-new-jersey-poised-name-official-state-microbe|title=Seriously? New Jersey poised to name official state microbe|date=2018-08-04|work=KYW|access-date=2018-09-06|language=en}}</ref> Electronic and print media coverage included the [https://www.app.com/story/news/local/new-jersey/2018/07/26/streptomyces-griseus-bacteria-could-become-njs-official-state-microbe/846292002/ Asbury Park Press] , [https://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2018/07/bacteria_discovered_in_nj_saved_millions_and_could_soon_be_our_official_state_microbe.html North Jersey dot com], the [http://www2.philly.com/philly/health/new-jersey-considers-state-microbe-20180801.html Philadelphia Enquirer], [https://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2018/07/bacteria_discovered_in_nj_saved_millions_and_could_soon_be_our_official_state_microbe.html NJ dot com], [http://nj1015.com/new-jerseys-mighty-microbe-may-finally-get-official-recognition/ NJ 101.5 dot com], [http://www.njspotlight.com/stories/18/06/20/animal-mineral-vegetable-microbe-parsing-njs-potential-list-of-state-symbols/ NJ Spotlight], [http://wpgtalkradio.com/new-jerseys-mighty-microbe-may-finally-get-official-recognition/ WPG Talk Radio], [https://news.rutgers.edu/rutgers-discovery-changed-world-may-become-new-jerseys-state-microbe/20180729#.W18F-VBKi72 Rutgers Today], [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/new-jersey-playbook/2018/07/27/senate-votes-to-strip-murphy-of-certification-power-anti-hugin-ads-funded-by-texas-billionaire-pooperintendent-resigns-291384 Politico], [https://wsus1023.iheart.com/featured/sarah-the-web-girl/content/2018-07-27-this-bacteria-could-become-njs-official-state-microbe/ WSUS], [https://news.sky.com/story/new-jersey-could-have-an-official-life-saving-microbe-11456736 Sky News], and [https://news.sky.com/story/new-jersey-could-have-an-official-life-saving-microbe-11456736 Isle of Wight Radio].
==Hawaii 2017: ''Flavobacterium akiainvivens'', pending== In 2017, legislation similar to the original 2013 bill to make ''[[Flavobacterium akiainvivens]]'' the state microbe was submitted in the Hawai{{okina}}i House of Representatives by [[Isaac Choy]]<ref name="HB1217">{{cite web|url=http://www.capitol.hawaii.gov/measure_indiv.aspx?billtype=HB&billnumber=1217&year=2017|title=HB1217|last1=Choy|first1=Isaac|author-link1=Isaac Choy|date=25 January 2017|website=Hawaii State Legislature|publisher=[[Hawaii State Legislature]]|location=Honolulu, HI|language=English|accessdate=22 October 2017}}</ref> and in the [[Hawaii Senate|Hawai{{okina}}i Senate]] by [[Brian Taniguchi]].<ref name="SB1212">{{cite web|url=http://www.capitol.hawaii.gov/measure_indiv.aspx?billtype=SB&billnumber=1212&year=2017|title=SB1212|last1=Taniguchi|first1=Brian|author-link1=Brian Taniguchi|date=25 January 2017|website=Hawaii State Legislature|publisher=[[Hawaii State Legislature]]|location=Honolulu, HI|language=English|accessdate=22 October 2017}}</ref> In January 2017, Representative Choy submitted HB 1217 in the [[Hawaii House of Representatives|Hawaiʻi House of Representatives]] and Senator Taniguchi submitted the mirror bill SB1212 in the [[Hawaii Senate|Hawaiʻi Senate]]. This continues the effort started by [[James Tokioka]] in 2013, and later contested in 2014 by Senator [[Glenn Wakai]]'s SB3124 bill proposing ''[[Aliivibrio fischeri]]'' instead. {{As of|2017|December}}, Hawaiʻi has no official state microbe.

{{other uses|Stipe (disambiguation)}} In [[botany]], a '''stipe ''' is a stalk that supports some other structure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ucmp.berkeley.edu/glossary/glossary_8.html|title=UCMP Glossary: Botany|publisher=University of California Museum of Paleontology|accessdate=2009-03-09}}</ref> The precise meaning is different depending on which taxonomic group is being described. <gallery> file:Helicteres-Yucatán-Flowers.jpg|The long stipe of a ''[[Helicteres]]'' flower ... file:Helicteres-Yucatán-Fruits.jpg|remains as each flower forms a fruit. </gallery>
[[Image:Cyathea medullaris.jpg|thumb|180px|Hexagonal stipe bases of the fern ''[[Cyathea medullaris]]'']] [[Image:Phalaenopsis orchid-Stipe.jpg|thumb|An orchid's stipe, with pollinia]] [[Image:Laminaria hyperborea.jpg|thumb|The stipe of a brown alga]] In the case of [[fern]]s, the stipe is only the [[Petiole (botany)|petiole]] from the [[rootstock]] to the beginning of the [[leaf]] tissue, or lamina. The continuation of the structure within the lamina is then termed a [[rachis]].
In flowering plants, the term is often used in reference to a stalk that sometimes supports a flower's [[ovary (plants)|ovary]]. In [[orchid]]s, the stipe or caudicle is the stalk-like support of the [[pollinium|pollinia]]. It is a non-viscid band or strap connecting the pollinia with the viscidium (the viscid part of the [[rostellum]] or beak).
A stipe is also a structure found in organisms that are studied by botanists but that are no longer classified as plants. It may be the stem-like part of the [[thallus (tissue)|thallus]] of a [[mushroom]] or a [[seaweed]], and is particularly common among [[brown algae]] such as kelp. The stipe of a kelp often contains a central region of cells that, like the [[phloem]] of vascular plants, serves to transport nutrients within the alga.
== See also == * [[Rachis]] * [[Stipe (mycology)]], the stalk supporting the fruiting body of some [[fungus|fungi]].

{{Infobox institute | name = Swedish Institute of Computer Science | image = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | latin_name = | motto = | founder = | established = {{Start date and age|1985}} | mission = | focus = Applied [[computer science]] | president = | ceo = | chairman = | head_label = | head = Ingrid Nordmark | faculty = 160 researchers | adjunct_faculty = | staff = 200 employees total | key_people = | budget = | endowment = | debt = | num_members = | subsidiaries = | owner = | non-profit_slogan = | former_name = | location = [[Kista]] district | city = [[Stockholm]] | state = [[Södermanland]] and [[Uppland]] | province = | country = [[Sweden]] | coor = {{coord|59.4049|N|17.9496|E|type:landmark|display=title}} | address = Box 1263,
SE-164 29 Kista,
Sweden | website = {{URL|www.sics.se}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }} RISE SICS (previously Swedish Institute of Computer Science) is a leading research institute for applied information and communication technology in Sweden, founded in 1985. RISE SICS is a research institute in the most expansive area of industry this century: the total digitalization of products, services and businesses. SICS is in the midst of this revolution, boosting the competitive strength of Swedish industry and the quality and efficiency of Sweden’s public sector. In January 2005, SICS had about 88 employees, of which 77 were researchers, 30 with PhD degrees. {{As of|2016|04}}, SICS had about 200 employees, of which 160 were researchers, 83 with [[PhD]] degrees. The institute is headquartered in the [[Kista]] district of [[Stockholm]], with the main office in the Electrum building. ==Software== Several well-known software packages have been developed at SICS: *[[Contiki]], an [[operating system]] for small-memory embedded devices *[[Delegent]], an authorization server *[[Distributed Interactive Virtual Environment]] or DIVE in short *[[lwIP]], a [[TCP/IP stack]] for [[embedded system]]s *[[Oz (programming language)|Oz-Mozart]], a multi-platform programming system *[[Nemesis (computing)|Nemesis]], a concept [[exokernel]] [[operating system]] *[[Protothreads]], light-weight stackless [[Thread (computing)|threads]] *[[Quintus Prolog]] and [[SICStus Prolog]], [[Prolog]] implementations *[[Simics]], a full-system simulator originally developed at SICS *[[uIP (micro IP)|uIP]], a [[TCP/IP stack]] for [[embedded system]]s ==Academic output== The research at SICS results in approximately 100 refereed publications in [[academic journal]]s, conferences and workshops per year. Around 2-4 SICS researchers receive higher [[academic degree]]s per year, and 1-3 persons move to academia for [[tenure]]d positions. SICS was ranked as the 15th most acknowledged computer science research institution in the world in an article in the December 2004 issue of the highly esteemed journal [[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences]] (PNAS). SICS is the only Swedish institution included in the list, and is one of two European institutions (the other one is [[INRIA]]) alongside 13 well-known American institutions, several of them larger than SICS.{{cite journal |doi=10.1073/pnas.0407743101 |title=Who gets acknowledged: Measuring scientific contributions through automatic acknowledgment indexing |journal=[[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A.]] |volume=101 |issue=51 |pages=17599–17604 |date=December 15, 2004 |last1=Giles |first1=C. L. |authorlink1=Lee Giles |last2=Councill |first2=I. G. |bibcode=2004PNAS..10117599G |url=http://clgiles.ist.psu.edu/papers/PNAS-2004-Acknowledgements.pdf|pmc=539757 }} ==Notable spin-off companies== * [[Dynarc]] (1997) * [[Effnet]] (1997) * [[Virtutech]] (1998) * [[PipeBeach]] (1998) * [[Tacton Systems]] (1998) - knowledge based solutions for sales and product configuration * [[BotBox]] (1999) * [[Voxi]] (1999) * [[VerySolid]] (2004) * [[Axiomatics]] (2006) - security solutions for digital data assets * [[Asimus]] (2006) - search technology * [[Peerialism]] (2007) - scalable and flexible file storage and video streaming solutions * [[Gavagai]] (2008) - scalable and robust representation of semantics of linguistic data ==Funding== SICS is owned jointly, 60% by the [[Swedish government]], and 40% by Swedish industry. The government owners are the [[Research Institutes of Sweden (RISE)]], Swedish ICT, and the [[Defence Materiel Administration (Sweden)|Defence Materiel Administration]] (FMV). The industry owners are a consortium of [[Ericsson]], [[Asea Brown Boveri]] (ABB), [[Saab Group]], [[Green Cargo]], [[Bombardier Transportation]], and [[TeliaSonera]]. SICS research is funded by the owners, by national funding sources, often [[Vinnova]] (the Swedish Government Agency for Innovation Systems) and the [[Swedish Foundation for Strategic Research]] (SSF), and by industrial collaboration partners. SICS also participates in several European research projects funded by the [[European Commission]]. ==History== RISE SICS was formed in 1985 and is owned by the [[Government of Sweden|Swedish Government]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|www.sics.se}} * [http://www.tacton.com Tacton home page] * [http://www.axiomatics.com/ Axiomatics homepage] * [http://www.gavagai.se/ Gavagai homepage] * [http://www.peerialism.se/ Peerialism home page] [[Category:Computer science institutes]] [[Category:Research institutes in Sweden]] [[Category:Members of the European Research Consortium for Informatics and Mathematics]] [[Category:Information technology research institutes]]
